metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: JavaScript Strings
Strings are for storing text
content.html: Strings are for storing text

content.text: Strings are written with quotes
content.html: Strings are written with quotes

content.text: Using Quotes
A JavaScript string is zero or more characters written inside quotes.
content.html: A JavaScript string is zero or more characters written inside quotes.

content.code_html: let text = "John Doe";

content.text: You can use single or double quotes:
content.html: You can use single or double quotes:

content.code_html:
let carName1 = "Volvo XC60";  // Double quotes
 let carName2 = 'Volvo XC60';  // Single quotes

content.text: Note
Strings created with single or double quotes work the same.
content.html: Strings created with single or double quotes work the same.

content.text: There is no difference between the two.
content.html: There is no difference between the two.

content.text: Quotes Inside Quotes
You can use quotes inside a string, as long as they don't match the quotes surrounding the string:
content.html: You can use quotes inside a string, as long as they don't match the quotes surrounding the string:

content.code_html:
let answer1 = "It's alright";
let answer2 = "He is called 'Johnny'";
let answer3 = 'He is called "Johnny"';

content.text: Template Strings
Templates were introduced with ES6 (JavaScript 2016).
content.html: Templates were introduced with ES6 (JavaScript 2016).

content.text: Templates are strings enclosed in backticks (`This is a template string`).
content.html: Templates are strings enclosed in backticks (`This is a template string`).

content.text: Templates allow single and double quotes inside a string:
content.html: Templates allow single and double quotes inside a string:

content.code_html: let text = `He's often called "Johnny"`;

content.text: Note
Templates are not supported in Internet Explorer.
content.html: Templates are not supported in Internet Explorer.

content.text: String Length
To find the length of a string, use the built-in length property:
content.html: To find the length of a string, use the built-in length property:

content.code_html:
let text = "ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ";
let length = text.length;

content.text: Escape Characters
Because strings must be written within quotes, JavaScript will misunderstand this string:
content.html: Because strings must be written within quotes, JavaScript will misunderstand this string:

syntaxHighlighting.text: let text = "We are the so-called "Vikings" from the north.";

content.code: let text = "We are the so-called "Vikings" from the north.";

syntax_highlighting.text: let text = "We are the so-called "Vikings" from the north.";

content.code_html: let text = "We are the so-called "Vikings" from the north.";

syntax_highlighting_data.text: let text = "We are the so-called "Vikings" from the north.";

content.text: The string will be chopped to "We are the so-called ".
content.html: The string will be chopped to "We are the so-called ".

content.text: To solve this problem, you can use an backslash escape character .
content.html: To solve this problem, you can use an backslash escape character.

content.text: The backslash escape character ( \ ) turns special characters into string characters:
content.html: The backslash escape character (\) turns special characters into string characters:

syntaxHighlighting.text: let text = "We are the so-called \"Vikings\" from the north.";
"We are the so-called \"Vikings\" from the north."

content.code: let text = "We are the so-called \"Vikings\" from the north.";

syntax_highlighting.text: let text = "We are the so-called \"Vikings\" from the north.";
"We are the so-called \"Vikings\" from the north."

content.code_html: let text = "We are the so-called \"Vikings\" from the north.";

syntax_highlighting_data.text: let text = "We are the so-called \"Vikings\" from the north.";
"We are the so-called \"Vikings\" from the north."

content.text: Six other escape sequences are valid in JavaScript:
content.html: Six other escape sequences are valid in JavaScript:

content.code_html:
Code Result
\b Backspace
\f Form Feed
\n New Line
\r Carriage Return
\t Horizontal Tabulator
\v Vertical Tabulator

content.text: Note
The 6 escape characters above were originally designed to control typewriters, teletypes, and fax machines. They do not make any sense in HTML.
content.html: The 6 escape characters above were originally designed to control typewriters, teletypes, and fax machines. They do not make any sense in HTML.

content.text: Breaking Long Lines
For readability, programmers often like to avoid long code lines.
content.html: For readability, programmers often like to avoid long code lines.

content.text: A safe way to break up a statement is after an operator:
content.html: A safe way to break up a statement is after an operator:

content.code_html:
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML =
"Hello Dolly!";

content.text: A safe way to break up a string is by using string addition:
content.html: A safe way to break up a string is by using string addition:

content.code_html:
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = "Hello " +
"Dolly!";

content.text: Template Strings
Templates were introduced with ES6 (JavaScript 2016).
content.html: Templates were introduced with ES6 (JavaScript 2016).

content.text: Templates are strings enclosed in backticks (`This is a template string`).
content.html: Templates are strings enclosed in backticks (`This is a template string`).

content.text: Templates allow multiline strings:
content.html: Templates allow multiline strings:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
`The quick
brown fox
jumps over
the lazy dog`

syntax_highlighting.text:
`The quick
brown fox
jumps over
the lazy dog`

content.code_html:
let text =
`The quick
brown fox
jumps over
the lazy dog`;

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
`The quick
brown fox
jumps over
the lazy dog`

content.text: Note
Templates are not supported in Internet Explorer.
content.html: Templates are not supported in Internet Explorer.

content.text: JavaScript Strings as Objects
Normally, JavaScript strings are primitive values, created from literals:
content.html: Normally, JavaScript strings are primitive values, created from literals:

content.code_html: let x = "John";

content.text: But strings can also be defined as objects with the keyword new :
content.html: But strings can also be defined as objects with the keyword new:

content.code_html: let y = new String("John");

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let x = "John";
let y = new String("John");

content.code:
let x = "John";
let y = new String("John");

syntax_highlighting.text:
let x = "John";
let y = new String("John");

content.code_html:
let x = "John";
let y = new String("John");

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let x = "John";
let y = new String("John");

content.text: Do not create String objects.
content.html: Do not create String objects.

content.text: The new keyword complicates the code and slows down execution speed.
content.html: The new keyword complicates the code and slows down execution speed.

content.text: String objects can produce unexpected results:
content.html: String objects can produce unexpected results:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let x = "John";
let y = new String("John");

content.code:
let x = "John";
let y = new String("John");

syntax_highlighting.text:
let x = "John";
let y = new String("John");

content.code_html:
let x = "John";
let y = new String("John");

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let x = "John";
let y = new String("John");

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let x = "John";
let y = new String("John");

content.code:
let x = "John";
let y = new String("John");

syntax_highlighting.text:
let x = "John";
let y = new String("John");

content.code_html:
let x = "John";
let y = new String("John");

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let x = "John";
let y = new String("John");

content.text: Note the difference between (x==y) and (x===y) .
content.html: Note the difference between (x==y) and (x===y).

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let x = new String("John");
let y = new String("John");

content.code:
let x = new String("John");
let y = new String("John");

syntax_highlighting.text:
let x = new String("John");
let y = new String("John");

content.code_html:
let x = new String("John");
let y = new String("John");

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let x = new String("John");
let y = new String("John");

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let x = new String("John");
let y = new String("John");

content.code:
let x = new String("John");
let y = new String("John");

syntax_highlighting.text:
let x = new String("John");
let y = new String("John");

content.code_html:
let x = new String("John");
let y = new String("John");

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let x = new String("John");
let y = new String("John");

content.text: Comparing two JavaScript objects always returns false .
content.html: Comparing two JavaScript objects always returns false.

content.text: Complete String Reference
For a complete String reference, go to our:
content.html: For a complete String reference, go to our:

content.text: Complete JavaScript String Reference .
content.html: Complete JavaScript String Reference.

content.text: The reference contains descriptions and examples of all string properties and methods.
content.html: The reference contains descriptions and examples of all string properties and methods.
